title: Rust compiler shows unused function warning when using modules with the path expression

labels.name: A-lint
labels.description: Area: Lints (warnings about flaws in source code) such as unused_mut.

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-incorrect
labels.description: A diagnostic that is giving misleading or incorrect information

labels.name: S-has-mcve
labels.description: A Minimal Complete and Verifiable Example has been found for this issue

body:
It seems like there's something wrong with how the warning works when it comes to modules, During some coding I had to divide into modules, some of them are located in `/src/utils/`, While some of the utils located there beside `main.rs` requires other utils to be able to work the only solution for me was to use the path expression `#[path = './module.rs']` then `mod module` to use it in my code

Using the module doesn't get read by the compiler, So I may be using `module::function` in my code and the compiler would still show me warning that I didn't use `function` in the module and it's an unused function that should be either removed or used 

Here's my directory structure 

```
./
./src/
./target/
.gitignore
Cargo.lock
Cargo.toml

./src/main.rs
./src/utils/

./src/utils/mod.rs
[more rs modules here]
...
```

The code works fine though, The function i'm using gets executed, it's just about the errors and how it's not supposed to be there since everything is working fine ig?
